frameDefinitions: The words in this frame refer to facial Expressions and the Possessors of those Expressions.
An Agent makes a particular facial expression, generally in response to some Internal_cause (generally an emotional state).
A perceptible Figure shows up against a Ground location due to Light shining on/from it, its salience possibly dependent on a Cause_of_shine.
The adjectives and nouns in this frame describe an Experiencer who is feeling or experiencing a particular emotional response to a Stimulus or about a Topic.
An Protagonist goes from a default state of mental and emotional equilibrium into a temporary state of disequilibrium, often a state of anger.
An Entity changes from a Prior_state to a Post_state in a sequence that follows a pre-defined plan, expectation, or model of change.
frameExamples: His eyes <t>smile</t>, but his lips do not.
Mr. Whiskers is <t>upset</t> that there are no more cat treats.
You totally <t>flipped</t> <t>out</t> on our waiter because of the mix-up with the bill.
Their offensive armament has <t>developed</t> from short range missiles to long-range ballistic weaponry in a relatively short period .
listRoleDefinitions: This is the <fen>Expression</fen> made.
This is the person who exhibitis the <fen>Expression</fen>.
The emotion that is conveyed by a particular <fen>Expression</fen>.
The individual that assumes a particular facial expression.
The particular part of the face that the <fen>Agent</fen> moves into a facial expression.
The point in time at which the change in facial_expression takes place.
The percept which is perceived at a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location.
The location of the phenomenon.
The <fen>Light</fen> which is emitted.  In this frame, it is usually incorporated in verbs and adjectives, and is the denotation of many of the nouns.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Figure</fen> is observed against the <fen>Ground</fen> location due to <fen>Light</fen> shining on it.
The spatial setting in which the <fen>Figure</fen> shows up against a <fen>Ground</fen> location.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
This is the person (or people) whose mental state changes.
Something done by the <fen>Protagonist</fen> as a result of losing mental equilibrium.
The object that undergoes change.
The time at which the progress occurs.
The location where the Progress occurs.
listRoleExamples: Hot coals glowed <fex>behind the fire grate</fex>.
<fex>In the morning</fex> the grass glistened with dew
<fex>Outside</fex> something was shimmering on the shore.
Nan Ho turned, <fex>his</fex> extreme agitation unnoticed by the Prince.
Liz's anger <fex>towards Raquel</fex> dates back to a charity dinner this year.
'Can I help you?' she asked, trying not to let him see the amusement <fex>in her blue eyes</fex>.
The end of the film was filled with jubilant <fex>scenes</fex>.
You totally lost it <fex>with that speech you just gave to the Principal</fex>.
Advances <fex>in marketing techniques</fex> have since rendered it obsolete.
<fex>When</fex> did the X-wing progress beyond the drawing board?
